title: Elliot Turiel
text:
Elliot Turiel (born 1938) is an <a href="United%20States%20born">United States born</a> psychologist and Chancellor’s Professor at the Graduate School of <a href="Education">Education</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20California%2C%20Berkeley">University of California, Berkeley</a>. He teaches courses on human development and its relation to education.
Education.
Turiel completed his PhD in Psychology from <a href="Yale%20University">Yale University</a> and was a student of <a href="Lawrence%20Kohlberg">Lawrence Kohlberg</a>, who had a strong influence on his work.
Research.
Turiel conducts research in the development of social judgments and action, the development of <a href="moral%20reasoning">moral reasoning</a>, children’s conceptions of <a href="authority">authority</a> and rules in school settings, as well as culture and social development. He has also been a <a href="Guggenheim%20Fellow">Guggenheim Fellow</a> and a National Institute of Mental Health Fellow. His area of specialization includes <a href="cognitive%20development">cognitive development</a>, Moral and <a href="ethics">ethical studies</a>, and social and emotional development.
